title: 3 Simple Ways to Install Adobe Flash Player on Ubuntu

steps.title: Open the Ubuntu Software Center.
steps.content: Open the Ubuntu Software Center. You can start it from the Ubuntu task bar.

steps.title: Click the Edit menu and select Software Sources.
steps.content: Click the Edit menu and select Software Sources .

steps.title: Check the "Software restricted by copyright or legal issues (multiverse)" box.
steps.content: Check the "Software restricted by copyright or legal issues (multiverse)" box. Click "Close".

steps.title: Wait for the Software Center to update sources.
steps.content: Wait for the Software Center to update sources. This may take a few minutes.

steps.title: Search for "Pepper Flash Player".
steps.content: Search for "Pepper Flash Player". Download the browser plugin. The package name will be "pepperflashplugin-nonfree", but it is a free plugin.

steps.title: Open the Terminal.
steps.content: Open the Terminal. You can start it from the task bar, or press Ctrl + Alt + T

steps.title: Type .
steps.content: Type . sudo update-pepperflashplugin-nonfree and press ↵ Enter .

steps.title: Wait for the installation to complete.
steps.content: Wait for the installation to complete. This may take a few moments. Once the installation is complete, your computer's name will appear again. Type exit and press ↵ Enter to close the terminal.

steps.title: Restart your browser.
steps.content: Restart your browser. Flash is now installed for Chromium.

steps.title: Check for updates periodically.
steps.content: Check for updates periodically. When Flash is installed this way, it will not update automatically. You will need to manually check for updates on a semi-regular basis. Open the Terminal. Type sudo update-pepperflashplugin-nonfree –status and press ↵ Enter to check for updates. If the available update is a higher number than your installed update, there is an update available. Type sudo update-pepperflashplugin-nonfree –install and press ↵ Enter to install the update. Restart your browser to complete the update.

steps.title: Update Chrome.
steps.content: Update Chrome. Flash is built-in to Chrome, and no extra effort is required to get it running. Simply keep Chrome up to date and Flash should work just fine. If Flash is broken in Chrome, try uninstalling and reinstalling it .

steps.title: Change browsers to Chrome or Chromium.
steps.content: Change browsers to Chrome or Chromium. Adobe is no longer supporting Linux development outside of the Pepper Flash plugin for Chrome. That means that the Flash plugin for Firefox is very outdated and is not receiving any improvements and only minor security patches. If you want to install the outdated version for Firefox, read on.

steps.title: Click CTRL + ALT + T at the same time- OR press "Super" key (windows key) and type in "Terminal."
steps.content: Click CTRL + ALT + T at the same time- OR press "Super" key (windows key) and type in "Terminal." Launch it "Terminal". You should see a terminal.

steps.title: Type in your administrative password for sudo.
steps.content: Type in your administrative password for sudo. You cannot view asterisks on the screen, but you're still typing it.

steps.title: Install the plugin by pressing "Y" (yes) on Terminal.
steps.content: Install the plugin by pressing "Y" (yes) on Terminal.

steps.title: Restart Firefox for the new plugin to take effect.
steps.content: Restart Firefox for the new plugin to take effect.
